choices.B: public Collection foo(Stream arg) { ... } overloads Foo.foo.
choices.A: public Collection foo (Collection arg) { ... } overrides Foo.foo.
choices.F: public Collection foo(Collection arg) { ... } overloads Foo.foo.
choices.E: public List foo (Collection arg) { ... } overrides Foo.foo.
choices.C: public Iterable foo{Collection arg) { ... } overrides Foo.foo.
choices.D: public Collection bar(Collection arg) { ... } overloads Foo.foo.

comments.content:
that is ok
a : is override 
b : is overload 
e: is override (List is a subtype of Collection, rule of override )

discussion.content:
answer : ABE
The bytecode after compilation with type erasure contains only normal classes, interfaces and methods, ensuring that no new types are produced.
public Collection foo(Collection arg) {...}
A) correct
B) correct different arguments so this overloads
C) not correct
Iterable is an interface so it is not a covariant type
E) correct
return type is a covariant to Collection
F) not correct
this is overrides see A

3 are valid:
A: overload
B: overrride
C: overload

choices.B: The code fails to compile as MyResource must implement Closeable.
choices.C: The code fails to compile as try-with-resource needs a variable declaration such as MyResource r1 = res1; MyResource r2 = res2;.
choices.D: The code fails to compile as res2 should be declared as final.

discussion.content: A is correct cause, Class implement autoclosable and can variables declarated before try catch

Selected Answer: C
answer : C
B is not correct
BiPredicate test = (Integer x, final Integer y) -> (x.equals(y));
BiPredicate - raw type same as BiPredicate<Object, Object>
BiPredicate<Object, Object> is not a subclass of BiPredicate<Integer, Integer>
but
BiPredicate test = (var x, var y) = x.equals(y);
is correct

questions.question_text: Which two are valid statements? (Choose two.)

choices.B: BiPredicate test = (Integer x, final Integer y) -> (x.equals(y))
choices.A: BiPredicate test = (Integer x, final var y) -> (x.equals(y));
choices.D: BiPredicate test = (final Integer x, var y) -> (x.equals(y));
choices.C: BiPredicate test = (var x, final var y) -> (x.equals(y));

questions.question_text:
Given the code fragment:

//IMG//


You must define the A exception class. The program execution must be terminated if the condition at line 19 is true and an A exception is thrown at line 20.

Which code fragment at line n1 defines A as per the requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
a IS CORRECT for finish program in line 20, others catch in exception clause an conitnue program

answer : A
B is not correct
According to the source code only exceptions extended from Throwable type and not from an Exception type are not caught. It could be Error or even checked type of exception.

Selected Answer: D
variables in lambdas must be a final or effectively final. If s is modified then code not compile
